In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define the `clean_column` function within a module to make it more reusable:

```julia
module DataCleaner
    # Function to clean column names by lowercasing and replacing spaces/hyphens with underscores
    function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
        return Symbol(lowercase(replace(col, " " => "_"); trim = true))
    end
end
```

Now you can use this function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
julia> using DataCleaner

julia> clean_column("My Column")
my_column

julia> clean_column("my column")
my_column

julia> clean_column("my-column")
my_column
```

The `clean_column` function uses the `lowercase` function from Julia's standard library to convert the string to lowercase and the `replace` function with a custom function as its first argument to replace spaces or hyphens with underscores. The `trim = true` parameter in the `replace` function specifies that leading and trailing whitespaces should be removed as well.

Remember to `using DataCleaner` at the top of your script if you want to use the `clean_column` function without specifying the module name every time.
